hero.title: "Why Does This Hurt So Much?" - You're Not Alone
hero.subtitle: If you've ever curled up in bed, wondering why your period feels like your body is rebelling, you're definitely not alone. About 80% of women experience period pain at some point.
hero.story: Sarah's Story: "I used to think severe period pain was just something I had to endure. It wasn't until I understood what was actually happening in my body that I felt empowered to manage it."

explanation.title: What's Actually Happening During Period Pain?

step1.title: Trigger
step1.description: Your body releases natural chemicals called prostaglandins (think of them as 'contraction messengers').

step2.title: Squeeze
step2.description: These chemicals tell your uterine muscles to contract.

step3.title: Pain
step3.description: Strong contractions can temporarily cut off the muscle's oxygen supply, causing cramp-like pain.

analogy.title: Simple Analogy:
analogy.description: This is similar to the feeling of a leg muscle cramping during exercise.

assessment.title: Is Your Period Pain Normal?
assessment.subtitle: Use our interactive assessment to understand your pain level and get personalized recommendations.

tracker.subtitle: Track your symptoms over time to identify patterns and find what works best for you.

heat.title: Heat Therapy - Your Best Friend
heat.description: Heat relaxes the uterine muscles and increases blood flow. Apply heat to your lower abdomen or back.
items: Heating pad (15-20 minutes at a time)

options.name: Ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin)
options.bestFor: Best Use: Take 1-2 days before your period starts or at the first sign of pain to prevent prostaglandins from forming.

options.name: Naproxen (Aleve)
options.bestFor: Best Use: Its longer-lasting effect is great for all-day or overnight relief.

options.name: Acetaminophen (Tylenol)
options.bestFor: Best Use: A good alternative if you have a sensitive stomach or cannot take NSAIDs like Ibuprofen.

immediateReliefPage.title: Immediate Relief Solutions for Period Pain
immediateReliefPage.description: Explore quick and effective methods to find relief from period pain when you need it most. Learn about techniques you can apply right now.
immediateReliefPage.introText: When period pain strikes, you need fast, effective ways to find comfort. This section is dedicated to immediate relief solutions ‚Äì methods you can turn to right now to help alleviate acute menstrual cramps and discomfort.
immediateReliefPage.introText2: We understand that finding quick relief is essential for getting through your day. The approaches suggested here focus on readily available techniques and remedies that can provide temporary but much-needed comfort.

gentleMovement.title: Gentle Movement & Breathing
gentleMovement.subtitle: Gentle and Effective Natural Relief Methods

acupressure.title: Acupressure
acupressure.subtitle: Traditional Chinese Medicine and Modern Medical Recognition

otcOptions.title: Over-the-Counter Options
otcOptions.subtitle: Safe and Effective Medication Relief Solutions

immediateReliefPage.findingWhatWorksText: Experimentation is key to discovering which immediate relief methods are most effective for your unique body and pain type. Consider combining different approaches for enhanced comfort.
immediateReliefPage.findingWhatWorksText2: Remember, these methods are for managing symptoms in the moment. For persistent, severe, or unusual pain, always consult a healthcare professional.
immediateReliefPage.heatTherapyDescription: Applying heat to the lower abdomen or back can help relax contracting uterine muscles and improve blood circulation, which may alleviate cramps.
immediateReliefPage.gentleMovementDescription: Light stretching, walking, or specific yoga poses can sometimes ease cramps by improving circulation and muscle relaxation. Deep breathing techniques can also help manage pain.

breathingExercise.subtitle: Scientifically Proven Nervous System Regulation Method

immediateReliefPage.breathingExerciseDescription: Activate the parasympathetic nervous system through 4-7-8 breathing technique to naturally reduce pain sensitivity. Research shows it can reduce pain perception by 40%.
immediateReliefPage.acupressureDescription: Applying pressure to specific points on the body may help reduce pain signals and provide relief from menstrual cramps.
immediateReliefPage.otcOptionsDescription: Understanding common non-prescription options and their basic mechanisms can be helpful, although professional medical advice is crucial for safe and effective use.
immediateReliefPage.workTipsTitle: Quick Tips for Managing Cramps at Work
immediateReliefPage.workTipsDescription: Practical strategies for finding relief during your workday when period pain strikes.
immediateReliefPage.meditationDescription: A quick guided meditation practice designed specifically to help manage menstrual pain.
immediateReliefPage.disclaimerText: The information provided on this page is for educational purposes only and is not intended to be a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. Always seek the advice of your physician or other qualified health provider with any questions you may have regarding a medical condition.

medicalDisclaimer.content: The information provided on this page is for educational purposes only and is not intended to replace professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment. If you have any medical concerns, please consult your doctor or other qualified healthcare provider.

faq.effectiveTherapies: Which natural therapies are most effective for menstrual pain?
faq.effectiveTherapiesAnswer: According to evidence-based medical research, the most effective natural therapies include: heat therapy (92% effectiveness), acupuncture (85% effectiveness), transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (76% effectiveness), and aromatherapy (68% effectiveness). These methods work through different physiological mechanisms to relieve pain, and it's recommended to choose appropriate methods based on individual constitution and pain severity.
faq.timeToEffect: How long does it take for natural therapies to take effect?
faq.timeToEffectAnswer: Different therapies have different onset times: heat therapy typically takes effect within 15-20 minutes; acupuncture requires 3-5 treatments to see significant results; aromatherapy begins working within 30 minutes; yoga and exercise require 2-4 weeks of consistent practice to see long-term improvements. It's recommended to combine multiple methods and maintain patience and persistence.

culturalCharmsPage.title: Exploring Cultural Comfort: Charms and Traditional Healing Symbols
culturalCharmsPage.description: Explore the historical and cultural significance of charms, symbols, and traditional practices used for comfort and spiritual support.
culturalCharmsPage.introText: Throughout history and across diverse cultures, people have turned to symbols, objects, and traditional practices for comfort, protection, and support during times of vulnerability, including during menstruation. These practices are deeply rooted in cultural belief systems and folklore.
culturalCharmsPage.understandingText: Many cultures have traditions that involve using specific items or performing certain rituals believed to influence well-being, bring good fortune, or ward off negative energy. For some, this extends to seeking comfort or relief during challenging physical experiences like menstrual discomfort.
culturalCharmsPage.disclaimerText: The information presented here regarding cultural charms, traditional practices, and associated beliefs is for cultural and informational purposes only. These practices are rooted in tradition and belief systems and are not intended to be, and should not be interpreted as, a substitute for professional medical advice, diagnosis, or treatment.

communication.title: Communication Template Assistant
communication.description: Effective communication is key to getting support and resources. When pain severely affects work, a professional and concise sick leave email is crucial.

english.subject: Sick Leave Request - [Your Name] - [Date]
english.body:
I am writing to request a sick leave for today, [Date], due to severe menstrual pain (dysmenorrhea) that began this morning. The discomfort is making it difficult for me to concentrate and perform my duties effectively, and I do not feel well enough to commute.

To ensure my work responsibilities are covered, I would like to request to rest at home / work remotely for the day. I have already [briefly explain arrangements, e.g., "completed and sent the X report to [Colleague's Name]"] and will remain available by phone and email for any urgent matters.

I apologize for any inconvenience this may cause and appreciate your understanding and support.

templates.template: "Honey, I'm not feeling well today and might need more rest. If I seem uncomfortable, please don't worry."
"I'm experiencing some pain and my emotions might fluctuate. Can you understand and give me some time and space? I'll recover soon."
"Sorry, I'm not feeling well today and might not be at my best. Can we reschedule? I'll make it up to you!"
"I might come to the party but may need to leave early. If I look tired, please understand."
"Hello, I'm not feeling well today and may need to take half a day off to address health issues. I'll handle other matters as soon as possible."
"Sorry, I'm feeling unwell today and my work efficiency might be affected. Please prioritize urgent matters, and I'll complete other tasks as soon as possible."

anatomy.title: Key Anatomical Structures
anatomy.imageAlt: Female reproductive system anatomy highlighting menstrual pain areas

uterus.title: Uterus
uterus.description: The primary site of menstrual pain, composed of muscle and endometrial layers. Muscle contractions are the direct cause of pain.

endometrium.title: Endometrium
endometrium.description: Tissue that sheds during the menstrual cycle and is the main source of prostaglandin production.

ovaries.title: Ovaries
ovaries.description: The control center for hormone secretion, regulating the entire menstrual cycle and pain occurrence.

enzymeActivation.title: Enzyme Activation:
enzymeActivation.description: Phospholipase A2 in endometrial cells is activated, releasing arachidonic acid

synthesisPathway.title: Synthesis Pathway:
synthesisPathway.description: Cyclooxygenase (COX-1/COX-2) catalyzes arachidonic acid to synthesize prostaglandins

mainProducts.title: Main Products:
mainProducts.description: PGF2Œ± and PGE2 are key molecules causing uterine contractions and pain

uterineContraction.title: Uterine Muscle Contraction:
uterineContraction.description: PGF2Œ± stimulates strong uterine smooth muscle contractions, with intensity exceeding labor contractions

vasoconstriction.title: Vasoconstriction:
vasoconstriction.description: Causes reduced uterine blood flow, leading to local ischemia and metabolite accumulation

neuralSensitization.title: Neural Sensitization:
neuralSensitization.description: Activates pain nerve fibers, lowering pain threshold

inflammatoryResponse.title: Inflammatory Response:
inflammatoryResponse.description: Promotes release of inflammatory mediators, exacerbating pain and discomfort

estrogen.title: Estrogen
estrogen.increasesSensitivity: Increases uterine muscle sensitivity to prostaglandins

feedbackRegulation.title: Feedback Regulation
feedbackRegulation.balancePoint: Balance point: Hormonal imbalance is the root cause of menstrual pain

receptors.title: Receptors:
receptors.description: Pain receptors in uterus and pelvic region

afferentNerves.title: Afferent Nerves:
afferentNerves.description: Conducted via sacral and lumbar sympathetic nerves

spinalProcessing.title: Spinal Processing:
spinalProcessing.description: Initial integration in spinal dorsal horn

centralPerception.title: Central Perception:
centralPerception.description: Transmitted to cerebral cortex to produce pain sensation

gateControlTheory.title: Gate Control Theory
gateControlTheory.description: Large fiber activation can inhibit pain signals, which is the physiological basis for the effectiveness of massage and heat therapy

endogenousAnalgesia.title: Endogenous Analgesia
endogenousAnalgesia.description: Release of endogenous opioid peptides like endorphins and enkephalins provides natural pain relief

descendingControl.title: Descending Control
descendingControl.description: Brainstem nuclei regulate spinal pain conduction

molecularTargets.title: üß¨ Molecular Target Research
molecularTargets.description: Novel drug development targeting key molecules like COX-2 and prostaglandin receptors, improving treatment efficacy while reducing side effects

genePolymorphism.title: Gene Polymorphism Research

epigeneticMechanisms.title: Epigenetic Mechanisms

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Find answers to common questions about menstrual health

q1.question: What are the fastest ways to relieve menstrual cramps?
q1.answer: The fastest menstrual cramp relief methods include: heat therapy on lower abdomen and back, gentle abdominal massage, light exercise like yoga, NSAIDs like ibuprofen, and adequate rest. Combining multiple methods works best.

q2.question: What is considered a normal menstrual cycle?
q2.answer: A normal menstrual cycle ranges from 21-35 days, with an average of 28 days. Menstruation typically lasts 3-7 days. Consult a gynecologist if cycles are consistently irregular.

q3.question: How does Traditional Chinese Medicine treat irregular periods?
q3.answer: TCM treats irregular periods through syndrome differentiation: acupuncture to regulate qi and blood, herbal formulas, dietary therapy, and lifestyle adjustments. Professional TCM diagnosis is needed for personalized treatment.

q4.question: When is the most effective time to take Ibuprofen?
q4.answer: Ibuprofen is most effective when taken at the onset of pain, typically taking effect in 30-60 minutes. It's recommended to take it when pain first starts or when you anticipate pain coming, rather than waiting until the pain becomes severe.

q5.question: How many times can I take Ibuprofen per day?
q5.answer: Ibuprofen can be taken every 6-8 hours, up to 4 times per day. Adult single dose is 200-400mg, with a maximum total daily dose of 2400mg. Do not use continuously for more than 3 days; consult a doctor if pain persists.

q6.question: Which has fewer side effects: Naproxen or Ibuprofen?
q6.answer: Naproxen typically has fewer side effects because it's taken less frequently (every 8-12 hours). However, both may cause stomach discomfort, so it's recommended to take with food. Those with stomach, heart, or kidney/liver problems should use with caution.

q7.question: Can I take both Ibuprofen and Naproxen together for period pain?
q7.answer: It's not recommended to take both Ibuprofen and Naproxen together as they are both NSAIDs, which increases the risk of side effects. Choose one medication, and if it's not effective, consult a doctor to adjust your medication plan.

scene1.title: Scene 1: Opening - Expressing Menstrual Discomfort
scene1.narration: Many women experience menstrual cramps every month, with that spasmodic, painful feeling that is very uncomfortable.

scene2.title: Scene 2: Explaining Menstrual Pain Causes - Prostaglandins
scene2.text: During menstruation, the endometrium releases a substance called 'prostaglandins'. Prostaglandins cause intense uterine muscle contractions, leading to pain.

scene3.title: Scene 3: Introducing NSAIDs
scene3.text: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, or NSAIDs for short, are commonly used medications for menstrual pain relief. They can reduce prostaglandin production at the source.

scene4.title: Scene 4: Taking Medication
scene4.text: When you take an NSAID tablet, it enters your digestive system.

scene5.title: Scene 5: Absorption into Bloodstream
scene5.text: It is then absorbed into the bloodstream through the digestive tract and flows throughout the body with the blood.

scene6.title: Scene 6: Distribution to Target Sites
scene6.text: Drug molecules circulate with the blood and eventually reach the areas causing pain - such as around your uterus.

scene7.title: Scene 7: Mechanism of Action - Inhibiting COX Enzymes
scene7.text: Here, NSAID drugs find the key 'factory' that produces prostaglandins - cyclooxygenase enzymes - and inhibit their activity.

scene8.title: Scene 8: Reducing Prostaglandins
scene8.text: With cyclooxygenase activity interrupted, prostaglandin synthesis is greatly reduced.

scene9.title: Scene 9: Pain Relief
scene9.text: As prostaglandins decrease, uterine contractions become gentler, and pain is significantly reduced.

scene10.title: Scene 10: Drug Metabolism
scene10.text: After completing their task, NSAID drugs are metabolized by the liver and eventually excreted through the kidneys.

scene11.title: Scene 11: Summary
scene11.text: This is the complete process of how NSAIDs relieve menstrual pain: from ingestion to absorption, from action to metabolism - scientific and effective.

step1.title: Trigger
step1.description: Your body releases natural chemicals called prostaglandins (think of them as 'contraction messengers').

header.title: Period Pain or Health Alert? A Doctor's Guide to 7 Red Flags
header.subtitle: When "monthly torture" becomes a health alert, learning to listen to your body's signals is crucial.

section1.title: Period Pain: Normal Physiology or Health Alert?
section1.quote: "Doctor, I experience excruciating pain every period. Is this normal?" - This is one of the most common questions in gynecology clinics.
section1.p1: Dysmenorrhea, medically known as menstrual pain, is a physiological phenomenon experienced by many women. But what level of pain is normal? When should you seek medical help? These questions often confuse women.
section1.p2: As a gynecologist, I want to tell you: pain is a signal from your body. Learning to correctly interpret these signals is the first step in protecting your health.
section1.p3: In this article, I will detail 7 critical red flags requiring medical attention and provide practical assessment tools to help you make informed medical decisions.
section1.li1: How to distinguish normal period pain from abnormal pain
section1.li2: 7 critical red flags requiring immediate medical attention
section1.li3: Practical pain assessment and symptom self-check tools
section1.p4: Remember: your health is your right to understand and protect.

section2.title: Step 1: Quantify Your Pain Level
section2.p1: Pain is subjective, but we can quantify it using standardized assessment methods. The medical pain scale (0-10) can help you more accurately describe your symptoms.
section2.p2: Use the pain assessment tool below to honestly evaluate your pain level:
section2.li1: 0-3 points: Mild discomfort, doesn't affect daily activities
section2.li2: 4-6 points: Moderate pain, affects some daily activities
section2.p3: Please move the slider to select the value that best matches your pain level:

section3.title: Identify 7 Critical Red Flags Requiring Medical Attention
section3.p1: The following symptom checklist is based on International Gynecological Association diagnostic standards. Please carefully check if you have any of these symptoms:
section3.p2: Sudden Severe Pain: If pain suddenly intensifies to unbearable levels, it may indicate ovarian cyst rupture, torsion, or other acute gynecological conditions.
section3.p3: Abnormal Bleeding Patterns: Sudden doubling of menstrual flow or large clots (>2.5cm diameter) may indicate uterine fibroids, adenomyosis, or coagulation disorders.
section3.p4: Fever and Systemic Symptoms: Period pain with fever (>38¬∞C), nausea, vomiting, dizziness, or fatigue may indicate pelvic inflammatory disease or infection.
section3.p5: Sudden Pain Pattern Changes: Previously regular period pain becoming irregular or changing in nature requires ruling out organic diseases.
section3.p6: Non-menstrual Pain: Pelvic pain occurring outside menstrual periods may indicate endometriosis, chronic pelvic inflammatory disease, etc.
section3.p7: Progressively Worsening Pain: Each period more painful than the last, with decreasing effectiveness of pain medication, highly suspicious of endometriosis.
section3.p8: After proper use of NSAIDs (like ibuprofen) for 3 menstrual cycles, pain shows no significant improvement, requiring further investigation.
section3.quote: Important Reminder: If you have any emergency signal, seek immediate medical care. If you have 2 or more high-risk symptoms, consider seeing a doctor within 48 hours.

section4.title: Smart Medical Decision Tree: 3 Steps to Determine if You Need Medical Care
section4.p1: Based on your symptom assessment results, use the decision tree below to determine whether you need medical care and the urgency level:

section5.title: Summary: Scientific Period Pain Management, Protecting Women's Health
section5.p1: Period pain is not a "fate" women must endure. Proper assessment and timely medical intervention can significantly improve quality of life.
section5.p2: Through this article's assessment tools, you've learned how to scientifically evaluate your symptoms. Remember, any symptom that concerns you is worth consulting a professional doctor.
section5.p3: Finally, I want to emphasize: caring for your body and listening to your body's signals is a life skill every woman should master.

callout.title: Next Step Recommendations
callout.text: If assessment results recommend medical care, don't delay. Prepare symptom records, choose appropriate appointment times, and actively communicate your concerns with your doctor.

3.rec2: Focus on rest and staying warm

4.rec2: Avoid strenuous exercise, get adequate rest

6.rec1: Recommend consulting doctor to adjust treatment plan

7.rec1: Recommend seeing doctor within this cycle

8.title: Extremely Severe Pain

8.rec1: Recommend seeking medical care promptly, don't delay
8.rec2: If pain suddenly worsens, consider emergency care

9.advice: Pain nearly unbearable, seriously affecting quality of life, requires urgent medical evaluation.
9.rec2: Prepare for medical visit, may need emergency treatment

10.title: Unbearable
10.advice: Pain completely unbearable, this is a medical emergency requiring immediate care.
10.rec1: Seek immediate medical care or call emergency services
10.rec2: Don't go to hospital alone, seek assistance

s1.text: Sudden severe pain, pain level suddenly changing from mild to unbearable
s1.description: May indicate ovarian cyst rupture, torsion, or other acute gynecological conditions requiring emergency medical evaluation

s2.text: Sudden significant increase in menstrual flow with clots larger than 2.5cm diameter
s2.description: May indicate uterine fibroids, adenomyosis, or coagulation disorders requiring urgent examination

s3.text: Period pain accompanied by fever (>38¬∞C), nausea, vomiting, or severe dizziness
s3.description: May indicate pelvic infection or other serious complications requiring immediate medical care

s4.text: Sudden change in pain pattern, previously regular period pain becoming irregular or changing in nature
s4.description: Changes in pain characteristics may indicate new pathological changes requiring medical evaluation

s5.text: Persistent pelvic pain or lower abdominal pain outside menstrual periods
s5.description: May indicate endometriosis, chronic pelvic inflammatory disease, or other conditions

s6.text: Progressively worsening pain, each period more painful than the last, with decreasing effectiveness of pain medication
s6.description: Progressively worsening pain highly suspicious of endometriosis or other conditions

s7.text: After proper use of ibuprofen or other pain medication for 3 menstrual cycles, pain shows no significant improvement
s7.description: Medication ineffectiveness suggests possible organic disease requiring further investigation

comparisonTable.concerningNote: These situations recommend seeking professional medical help
comparisonTable.mobileHint: Tip: Click table rows to view more detailed information

painIntensity.normal: Mild to moderate pain (1-6 points), tolerable, doesn't seriously affect daily activities
painIntensity.concerning: Severe pain (7-10 points), unbearable, seriously affects work and life
painIntensity.action: Recommend medical evaluation when pain score ‚â•7

painDuration.normal: Pain lasts 1-3 days, mainly concentrated 1-2 days before period and first day of menstruation
painDuration.concerning: Pain lasts more than 3 days, or severe pain throughout entire menstrual period
painDuration.action: Recommend gynecological examination if pain lasts >3 days

painLocation.normal: Central lower abdominal pain, may radiate to lower back and inner thighs
painLocation.concerning: Pain location varies, or accompanied by distinct sharp pain on one side
painLocation.action: Atypical pain locations require medical evaluation

associatedSymptoms.normal: Mild nausea, fatigue, mood changes - symptoms are mild and tolerable
associatedSymptoms.concerning: Severe nausea and vomiting, fever, dizziness and fainting, heavy bleeding
associatedSymptoms.action: Seek immediate medical care for severe associated symptoms

medicationResponse.normal: Over-the-counter pain medication (like ibuprofen) effectively relieves pain
medicationResponse.concerning: Pain medication completely ineffective, or requires increasingly larger doses for relief
medicationResponse.action: Need professional treatment plan when medication is ineffective

dailyImpact.normal: Mild impact, can work and study normally with appropriate rest
dailyImpact.concerning: Severe impact, unable to work or study normally, requires bed rest
dailyImpact.action: Recommend medical care when quality of life is severely affected

cycleChanges.normal: Pain pattern relatively stable, similar pain level each menstrual period
cycleChanges.concerning: Pain gradually worsening, or sudden change in pain pattern
cycleChanges.action: Changes in pain pattern require medical evaluation of causes

beginner.title: Beginner

intermediate.title: Intermediate

beginner.title: Warm Heart Beginner
beginner.description: You have a caring heart, which is more important than anything! Although your understanding of dysmenorrhea is still basic, your sincerity and participation are the best start. Every caring gesture will make her feel your love.

recommendations.0: Start with the basics. Spend 5 minutes daily learning basic knowledge about dysmenorrhea, such as "why dysmenorrhea occurs" and "when to pay attention".
recommendations.1: Learn to listen. When she says "my stomach hurts", don't rush to give advice. First ask "What can I do for you?" to let her feel your care.

intermediate.title: Caring Guardian
intermediate.description: You have mastered the basic knowledge of dysmenorrhea and can provide warm emotional support. You know when to give a hot water bottle and when to quietly accompany. Your care makes her feel safe and understood.

recommendations.0: Learn basic massage techniques. Master simple abdominal massage methods to provide practical help when she says it hurts.
recommendations.1: Prepare caring items. Such as hot water bottles, heating pads, brown sugar water, etc., to let her feel your thoughtful preparation.

advanced.title: Understanding Expert
advanced.description: Congratulations! You already have excellent dysmenorrhea understanding ability and can provide support from both emotional and physical levels. You know her emotional changes and understand how to provide the most appropriate help.

recommendations.0: Create a care plan. Discuss pre and post-menstrual precautions with her and create your own "care checklist".
recommendations.1: Become her support. Let her know that during her period, you are her most reliable support and she doesn't need to tough it out.

expert.title: Caring Expert
expert.description: You have reached the highest level of the basic test! Your understanding and caring ability for dysmenorrhea has surpassed most men. Your girlfriend is lucky to have such a caring partner.

recommendations.0: Share your experience. Help other male friends learn how to better understand and support their partners.
recommendations.1: Continue learning. Although you performed excellently in the basic test, the professional test will give you deeper medical knowledge.

beginner.title: Professional Care Novice
beginner.description: You have basic medical knowledge but need to learn professional dysmenorrhea management knowledge in depth. Through systematic learning, you will master scientific support methods and become her most reliable professional supporter.

recommendations.0: Learn medical basics. Understand professional terms like prostaglandins, endometrial shedding, and master the physiological mechanisms of dysmenorrhea.
recommendations.1: Build scientific cognitive framework. Distinguish between primary and secondary dysmenorrhea, learn to identify symptoms that require medical intervention.

intermediate.title: Professional Support Partner
intermediate.description: You have mastered considerable professional knowledge and can understand the complexity of dysmenorrhea from a medical perspective. You not only have empathy but also scientific support methods, able to provide precise professional guidance.

recommendations.0: Master professional nursing skills. Learn professional pain assessment methods, master scientific relief techniques and medication knowledge.
recommendations.1: Develop scientific support plans. Create personalized menstrual management plans based on her specific situation.

advanced.title: Professional Empathy Expert
advanced.description: Congratulations! You not only have professional medical knowledge but also perfect empathy ability. You can provide support from both scientific and emotional dimensions, making you a professional "super teammate" that 90% of men cannot match.

recommendations.0: Create professional emergency plans. Based on medical knowledge, work with her to develop scientific "menstrual emergency plans" including symptom monitoring, medication preparation, medical contacts, etc.
recommendations.1: Become a professional mentor. Use your professional knowledge to help other couples establish scientific menstrual management methods.

expert.title: Professional Care Master
expert.description: You have reached the highest level of professional testing! You not only have deep medical knowledge but also perfect professional judgment and action ability. You are a medical-level partner support expert and a professional role model for all men to learn from.

recommendations.0: Share professional experience. Use your professional knowledge to help more male friends master scientific partner support methods.
recommendations.1: Become a professional mentor. Guide other couples to establish medical knowledge-based menstrual management systems and communication patterns.
recommendations.2: Continue professional learning. Stay updated with the latest medical research and continuously improve professional support abilities.

exercises.name: Seated Pelvic Clock Movement
exercises.description: Relieves sacroiliac joint pressure and improves lower back blood circulation
steps: Sit on the edge of the chair with feet flat on the ground
Imagine the pelvis as a clock, slowly draw circles
Do one set clockwise and one counterclockwise

exercises.name: Hidden Foot Massage
exercises.description: Use fascia ball under desk to promote lower limb blood return
steps: Place a small massage ball under the desk
Remove shoes and roll the ball with the sole of your foot
Focus on pressing the arch and heel areas

exercises.name: Water Cooler Side Stretch
exercises.description: Natural standing posture to relieve waist tension
steps: Stand by the water cooler with feet shoulder-width apart
One hand on waist, the other reaching up
Bend body to one side, feel the side stretch

communication.title: Communication Template Assistant
communication.description: Effective communication is a key step in obtaining support and resources. When pain seriously affects work, a professional and concise leave request email is crucial.

leaveRequest.title: Period Pain Leave Request Email Template
leaveRequest.subtitle: Bilingual Chinese-English

chinese.subject: Leave Request - [Your Name] - [Date]
chinese.body:
Due to severe menstrual discomfort (dysmenorrhea) this morning, I find it difficult to concentrate and work efficiently. My physical condition also prevents me from commuting. To ensure work quality and recover quickly, I would like to request to rest at home/work remotely for today.

I have already [briefly explain arrangements, e.g., "completed and sent the X report to [Colleague's Name]"] and will remain available by phone and email for any urgent matters.

I apologize for any inconvenience and thank you for your understanding and support.

english.subject: Sick Leave Request - [Your Name] - [Date]
english.body:
I am writing to request a sick leave for today, [Date], due to severe menstrual pain (dysmenorrhea) that began this morning. The discomfort is making it difficult for me to concentrate and perform my duties effectively, and I do not feel well enough to commute.

To ensure my work responsibilities are covered, I would like to request to rest at home / work remotely for the day. I have already [briefly explain arrangements, e.g., "completed and sent the X report to [Colleague's Name]"] and will remain available by phone and email for any urgent matters.

I apologize for any inconvenience this may cause and appreciate your understanding and support.

templates.template: "Dear, I'm not feeling well today and may need more rest. If I seem a bit uncomfortable, please don't worry."
"I'm experiencing some pain now and may have mood swings. Can you understand and give me some time and space? I'll recover soon."
"Sorry, I'm not feeling well today and may not be at my best. Can we reschedule for next time? I'll make it up to you!"
"I might come to the party but may need to leave early. If I seem a bit tired, you understand."
"Hello, I'm not feeling well today and may need to take half a day off to handle physical issues. I'll finish other tasks as soon as possible."
"Sorry, I'm not feeling well today and my work efficiency may be affected. If there are urgent matters, please prioritize them, and I'll complete other tasks as soon as possible."

acupressure.title: Office Acupressure Points
acupressure.description: Simple and easy-to-learn acupressure techniques that can be performed discretely in the office for quick pain relief.

points.name: Hegu Point (LI4)
points.location: Between thumb and index finger, in the web
points.benefits: Regulates liver qi, promotes blood circulation, relieves general pain
points.technique: Press with thumb pad, moderate pressure, 30 seconds each time
points.officeUse: Can be done discretely during meetings without attracting attention

points.name: Sanyinjiao Point (SP6)
points.location: Inner side of calf, three inches above ankle joint
points.benefits: Regulates qi and blood, specifically relieves gynecological pain
points.technique: Press with thumb, combine with deep breathing, 1-2 minutes each time
points.officeUse: Can be done under desk, removing shoes for better effect

scientificBasis.title: Scientific Basis
scientificBasis.description: Acupressure works by stimulating specific nerve points to promote endorphin release, which is the body's natural pain-relieving substance. Modern research shows that appropriate acupoint stimulation can regulate nerve conduction and relieve pain perception.
